newsitem.title: UK: EMU with Italy, Spain a "lethal combination"-UK MP.
newsitem.headline: EMU with Italy, Spain a "lethal combination"-UK MP.

text.p: European Monetary Union including the southern European countries would be a "lethal combination" of economic instability, inflexible policies and no democratic accountability, a British politician said on Thursday.

Well-known "Eurosceptic" member of parliament, David Heathcoat-Amory, said a single currency including countries such as Italy and Spain, with their history of economic instability, would put excessive strain on the system.

At the same time, a single currency did not allow for any differences in economic circumstances, nor did it allow for any democratic or political representation, he told a conference on European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) in London.
"Macroeconomic instability, inappropriate interest rates and unrelieved stresses and strains will be the result," he said.
He said he thought it was Germany's original intention that EMU be confined to a small group of strong northern European economies.
"But it hasn't quite worked out that way," Heathcoat-Amory said, referring to Spain and Italy's drive to clean up their economic acts and aim for EMU in 1999.
"Once you start to include those other currencies, it ceases to be an optimal currency," he said.
Heathcoat-Amory said he expected the British public would find an independent European Central Bank (ECB) intolerable and would eventually reject EMU.
But he added: "There is such enormous amount of momentum behind it that I think it will happen."
Sir Alan Walters, vice-chairman of AIG Trading Group, and former economic adviser to former prime minister Margaret Thatcher, decried the fact that EMU included no escape valve.
"You've got this irrevocability, no mention of escape clauses," he told the conference.

He said the drive to EMU was largely political and the European public were being railroaded into it at an enormous pace by countries' elites. "Don't try and force convergence by a hot-house atmosphere -- all you get is spindly growth and eventual collapse," he said.
